project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
In Control Charts, currently, the issue history is utilized and the time spent in transitions are used for calculating the data and plotting the diagram. 

At the moment there is no possibility to see or find out the individual issues that are contributing to the control chart other than hovering the mouse over each dot.

Like we do for the Burndown chart in Scrum, it will be benefical to have a table of issues, sorted in the order of date in which the events appear (the same order in which Control chart calculates the values).

Current system of hovering the mouse over an issue is tedious and error prone.

(!) This request also is due to the fact that currently, when two issues happen to be on the same spot in the Control Chart, there is no way to find out that there are two issues at that location by hovering the mouse over it.
fields.summary: As a user I need the details of the issues that are used for the Control Chart calculation

fields.description:
As of now, the current feature has the ability to edit the *Start Date* and the *End Date* of a sprint. 

Looking at the screenshot attached, you can see that we were able to change the sprint start date from *Nov 1* to *Oct 22*, that's not a problem. 
!burndown_chart.png!

The issue is that the other *sprint* event dates (you can see them at the bottom of the screenshot listed as event type *Scope change*) cannot be modified anywhere. It will be useful if there is a feature introduced that allows users to be able to modify these dates.
fields.summary: Ability to alter the timing for ALL sprint events

fields.description:
h3. Summary: 

Non-working days are not being respected in the Classic Chart Board.

h3. Steps to Reproduce:

# Set the JVM timezone to {{America/Sao_Paulo}}.
# Create a Chart Board.
# Manually set a NWD.
# It will not be used.

h3. Expected Results:

The NWD is not displayed.

h3. Actual Results:

The NWD is displayed.

h3. Regression:

Unsure of any regression.

h3. Notes:

This is caused by a known bug in JIRA, [JRA-19533|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-19533] and is being tracked there.
fields.summary: Manually added non-working days are still displayed in the Classic Chart Board

fields.description:
COS: 
- Show change history every time a new issue is attached or detached from the Epic
- When multiple issues are attached to an epic at once log just one change history entry
- When multiple issues are detached from an epic at once log just one change
- Can't use the Epic Link field (because that's always from Child to Parent)

(!) Testing Notes (!)

Q: Which events are tracked in the history? Are there any special events for issues that are either not tracked or different for epics?
A: Just adding / removing issues, no special events.

Q: Can you backdate changes?
A: No

Q: What happens to the change history for completing an epic and reopening it?
A: History of added / removed issues shouldn't be affected.

Q: What happens to the change history when estimating stories in that epic?
A: Nothing
fields.summary: As a user, I'd like to see change history for my Epic in the history tab for the Epic

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Click on add story to epic, then choose a project that is not on the board. You're greeted with an error when creating the issue.

The problem is that we try to reuse the issue loaded from the backlog in order to assign it to the epic. This does not work if the issue won't appear on the board!

Split the logic to separately fetch issue types after creating the issues and use that information to assign the issues to the epic. THEN reload the backlog.
fields.summary: Creating an issue through "Add story to epic" that isn't on the board results in NPE

fields.description:
When a user first drags an issue vertically (thus reranks) before transitioning the rerank and transition operations happen in parallel.

If on the serve the transition operation happens in the middle of the rerank operation then it can happen that the index won't contain the status change information. The result is that the issue will show up in an incorrect column.

Fix is to not execute the rank operation when initiating a transition operation, which we already do on Plan mode.
fields.summary: Work mode concurrent transition/rank operation can result in incorrect reindexing

fields.description:
We have built up a hierachy of issues types "Feature", "User Story" and "Story Task" - with custom coding for automatic issue links, status synchronization, custom field inheritance, effort accumulation and reporting. 2,000 users wordwide.

An issue type "Epic" would break our complete logic and infrastructure. therefore we need to be sure, that GreenHopper remains fully functional and consistent without issue type "Epic".

The UI must not have any references to "Epic" in this case.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:

# Login as a user 'admin' and Create a scrum board
# Start a sprint, have few issues with sub-task and one issue with no sub-task(in the example here, TEST-3 does not have sbu-task)
!sprint.JPG|thumbnail!
# Go to work board, Collapse one of the story swimlanes, let' say TEST-12 in this example.
!work1.JPG|thumbnail!
# Ensure, none of the subtasks is selected, or you can delete the &selectedIssue= part in the URL, for example: http://localhost:8080/secure/RapidBoard.jspa?rapidView=5
# Sign in as another user in a different browser, let's say user 'test' and rank the collapsed issue to lower/higher
!sprint2.JPG|thumbnail!
In the upper example, if we move an issue with no sub-task it will not effect anything on the work board, but if we move some issue with subtask, as below:
!sprint3.JPG|thumbnail!
# Go back to the user admin's work board page and Refresh the page
# The collapsed state remains, but the state is not stick to your ticket. Your ticket will be open, and the one took your ticket's rank - will be collapsed. As showing below:
!work2.JPG|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Story swimlane collapsed state is not updated when ranking changed

fields.description:
COS: 
- Similar to existing Sprint Report
- Include key, summary and current estimate

(!) Testing Notes (!)

Q: What if issues are removed and readded to an epic?
A: the report represents current state only

Q: What happens to the table if there are negative estimates?
A: same thing as sprint report

Q: What if the epic is visible on the board, does not contain any issues on that board, but contains issues from another project? What will be displayed in the table?
A: no issues - report is dependent on the board query

Q: What if the estimation config is removed/modified from issues on the board?
A: report represents current estimation config as per sprint report
fields.summary: Show table at bottom of single Epic report that shows the estimate (current) for Done, Undone - Estimated, and Undone - Not Estimated stories

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
COS: 
- For a given epic return the history of all issues added and removed (with time) from the Epic
- Will need to inform admins that they need to re-index
- This does not involve the addition of JQL to assist in this querying

(!) Development Notes (!)

Q: I'm assuming this will only be seen on the view issue page?
A: It won't be seen in the UI anywhere. It will only be seen by accessing the URL directly. 

Q: What if the epic has been deleted?
A: You get an error message: issue does not exist. 

Q: What if the epic was converted to an issue/subtask?
A: It doesn't check. If you changed it in JIRA and there are still epic child links, you'll still see the data.

Q: What if the linked issue was moved/converted/deleted?
A: It should still show up in the appropriate group (incomplete, complete, punted)

Q: From what version forward will we be tracking this history? aka if an epic link already existed before we introduce this change?
A: previous epic links should be tracked

Q: Do any of these questions surprise you? If so, what hadn't you previously considered?
A: the first one, because it's not a UI story

Q: What else can you think of?
A: (x) Not Answered
fields.summary: Be able to query Epic assignment history of all issues ever assigned with an Epic

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Software Server*. Using *JIRA Software Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSWCLOUD-6594].
  {panel}

Epic -> Issue: Remove the epic link for all issues linked to that epic
Issue -> Epic: Remove epic link if was previously part of an Epic
Issue -> Subtask: Remove epic link to Epic if was linked
Subtask -> Issue: If old issue parent had epic then link issue to epic (to be discussed if we really want this), unless the new issue type is Epic

We shouldn't have to clean up epic label and epic color fields as these are only applicable to epics and therefore will automatically be cleared.

(!) Testing Notes (!)

Q: Make sure this plays well with the change to Epic Name field.
A: The two are completely unrelated

Q: What if subtasks are disabled either before or after trying to convert?
A: (/) Can't disable sub-tasks while there are sub-tasks in the system.

Q: Don't forget to add the Epic Link to the subtask if the parent has one.
A: Epics are always only linked to parent issues, not to subtasks

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Software Server*. Using *JIRA Software Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSWCLOUD-6590].
  {panel}

Per summary, please see the attached screenshot:
 
Steps to replicate:

# Go into a scrum board
# Click the plan tab
# Enter criteria into the 'Instant Filter' search box that matches at least one issue and hit enter

Result:

All issues remain visible, even though only one matches the criteria

Expected Result:

Only the matching issue should remain visible

Update: This works perfectly if Epics are enabled in GreenHopper:
!epics.png!

It occurs only when selected version has a Start Date in the past relative to today and do not have End Date or End Date is in the future, relative to today.
In the following cases, the error does not appear:
- Start Date not filled;
- Both, Start Date and End Date is in the past or both dates is in the future, relative to today;
- Start Date is today and End Date in the future;
- End Date is today and Start Date in the past.

We found an article:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/GHKB/Accessing+the+Chart+Board+leads+to+NullPointerException%3A+at+com.pyxis.greenhopper.charts.CurveChart.getRatioCurve
But this solution did not help.
It started around 6-Nov-2012.
On the server, the time is set to the correct time zone: UTC+03:00.
Jira's Default user time zone is set to "System default: (GMT+03:00) Moscow" and this is correct.

This is critical for us.
This makes it impossible to use the plugin.

Thanks.

PS: There is another bug: when specifying Start Date it saves as previos day. For example: Set Start Date to 12-11-2012 saves as 11-11-2012.
fields.summary: Setting the Start Date of a version will cause a NPE on Chart Board(Classic)

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
As seen in our [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/GH/Setting+Up+a+Version+Hierarchy], in GreenHopper Classic mode one can handle a hierarchy of fixVersions and charts based on them (since the essence of the Sprint is bound to the fixVersion field). This is a good enough tool to plan releases, see the trend of burning rate, able to predict a release date.

However, in the [GreenHopper Rapid Board|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/GH/Creating+a+Board], all work is organized in [Sprints|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/GH/Creating+a+Sprint], completely independent from the Project Version.

The current [workaround|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/42933/release-planning-in-rapid-board] is to create independent Rapid Boards. However, it would be nice if this could be an embedded feature in GreenHopper next versions.

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Hi,

a user having project administrator rights couldn't manage sprints any more. After having spent a significant amount of time double checking all permissions and comparing them with those of a Jira administration account (which could manage the sprints allright) it turned out to be the following:

the query used for the rapid board contained [OR Sprint != ""]. Apparently it is not allowed to show issues which already have been taken into Sprint (a GreenHopper Sprint Field). Once the user removed the condition from the query, he was again able to control Sprint lifecyle.

IMHO, it's a very well hidden trap to fall into. I would add a big caveat in the documentation (which only mentions project administration privilege as a criteria for sprint management) or run a sanity check on the rapid board query to warn the user of possible unintended consequences.


Best,
Edoardo
fields.summary: Scrum Board owner cannot complete sprint

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
When working in Kanban boards for projects that don't require an estimate process, we still need log our time spent working on the tickets. Currently, we need to open the ticket in the traditional issue detail's view in order to check if we have added any time already. We would like to have better visibility of the logged time without leaving the Greenhopper boards.

I see two possible solutions for this issue.

1. Add the "Logged time" to the Issue Details tab in the right hand side panel.

2. Add a new tab for "Work log" to the Issue Details panel on the right hand side.

I prefer option #2 as this would allow us to add/edit/delete our logged time without leaving the boards.
fields.summary: Add "Logged time" to the Issue Details tab or add "Work Log" tab

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
I have read articles by atlassian about the value of story points. This convinced us to use story points on stories. For our daily work we break our stories down to tasks. In order for our developers to get an idea of what they are doing they need to assign hours (up to a max of 4) to those tasks, eventually we are striving to leave out the hours, we're not there yet.

These hours are however not shown in the 'work' screen (agile board) on the cards. I noticed that they become visible when I change the 'Estimation Statistic' to 'Original time estimate'. I wonder if it's possible to show them in 'Story Points' mode as well.

I have read about the issue with card configuration (that it might hinder redesign of the cards). But since it's already on the card in one mode, I was wondering if you could add a checkbox that would allow it to always be displayed on the cards?
fields.summary: Card in work mode does not show hours when in story point mode

fields.description:
We would love to integrate Structure plugin with the new GreenHopper epics in the right way - through GreenHopper API. 

We would like to:
- query which epic an issue belongs to (receiving just issue ID would be fine)
- query which issues does an epic contain (likewise, issue IDs would do)
- change assigned epic for an issue
- get notified when an epic changes (can be done through the standard issue events -- as of version 6.0.6, no events are fired)

It would be awesome if we could:
- query epics in bulk, if that improves performance
- update epics in bulk, if that improves performance
fields.summary: As a plugin developer, I would like to have an API to the new Epics implementation

fields.description:
COS:
- 'Issues in Epic' panel

A: see above

fields.description:
1. Configure SCRUM Rapid board to have Swimlanes based on Stories and Estimation statistic based on Story Points
2. Create Story with 5 Story Points and multiple subtasks
3. Start Sprint with issues created above included
4. Move Sub-task to In Progress status

Expected results: When a subtask within a story is in progress, the parent story should also be marked as in progress. This should be reflected on the Plan mode, in the colored indicators for estimating how many issues are in each status. See screenshot for clarification

Current behavior: The parent Story status is what reflects the colored indicators estimation in Plan mode.
fields.summary: As a user I would like Sub-task status to be reflected in Plan mode estimation indicators (Swimlanes based on Stories)

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
No issues initially display in backlog because To Do status isn't mapped properly, or isn't a part of the workflow.

https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/102966/no-issues-displaying-in-scrum-backlog?page=1#102974

https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JST-49540

From Ticket:

Hi Dave,

I'm reporting a bug. When a new user creates a Scrum Board using the default method as described, he can create issues, but none of his issues will display in the Scrum backlog. I think this is an error in the Scrum Board creation code, which is incorrectly creating a Scrum Board using the "To do" status instead of the "Backlog" status. The "To do" status does not exist in the default workflow for Scrum.

The work-around for this error is to go to the settings and fix this manually. But this should be correctly done in the code, because without issues showing it's impossible to use the board, and it's not obvious why no issues are being displayed, especially to new users.

To replicate just create a new Scrum Board with the GreenHopper Simplified Workflow, and create some issues. You will see none show up in the board, until you do the manual work-around fix I described.
fields.summary: Default for Greenhopper does not map "To Do" status to backlog

project.name: Jira Software Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Summary of Bug
If an issue is in a running sprint, then if the board is deleted, the issue will still be listed as in the sprint. If a new board is created using the project with those issues, a sprint using the previous values will automatically be created.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Place some issues in a Scrum board
# Create a sprint, place the issues in the sprint, and start it

!sprint 2.png|thumbnail!
# While the sprint is still running, delete the board
# The issue will still be written as in a sprint

!sprint 1.png|thumbnail!
# Create a new board using the same project, and a sprint will automatically be created and started using the previous values

!sprint 3.png|thumbnail!

h3. Additional Details

* It seems that even after the board is deleted, the sprint field of the issue is not cleared, possibly causing this issue
fields.summary: Issue still in sprint even after board is deleted

fields.description:
The team I'm in had our 5 next sprints all planned out, which is something the Greenhopper planning UI somewhat encourages by saying "Plan some sprints".

Somebody accidentally deleted the second one by hitting the subtle grey (x) in the top corner of the sprint.

Re-adding it again is impossible.  We have to rename all the sprints and shuffle the work down each one.  Due to a single mis-click.

If adding sprints to the middle is impossible, I suggest that deleting them from the middle also should be.
fields.summary: As a user, I would like a confirmation when I delete a future sprint so that I don't accidentally lose all my work
